predictions.text: A U.S. federal judge will grant Ørsted (or its U.S. subsidiary) a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction that pauses or blocks the Trump administration’s halt/suspension of the Revolution Wind project, by 2026-02-28 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Court docket/order (PACER) or a Reuters/Bloomberg/WSJ/FT report citing the order confirms a TRO or preliminary injunction in Ørsted’s challenge that prevents enforcement of the federal halt (in whole or in material part) pending further proceedings.
evidence: Ørsted filed a legal challenge over Trump’s halt of a ~$5B offshore wind project (CNBC, 2026-01-02).
monitoring_signals: PACER filings: motion for TRO/preliminary injunction; hearing dates set
DOJ/agency filings opposing emergency relief
Public statements from BOEM/Interior on compliance timelines
Reuters/Bloomberg court-coverage alerts on Revolution Wind case
predictions.rationale: Emergency injunctive relief is a common first step in high-stakes permitting disputes, but courts often defer to agencies early on; timing is plausible within weeks.

predictions.text: The U.S. Department of the Interior (including BOEM) will issue a formal directive/memo or Federal Register notice imposing a new pause or suspension of offshore-wind leasing/permitting actions lasting at least 60 days, by 2026-04-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Interior/BOEM publishes an official directive, order, or Federal Register notice stating a pause/suspension affecting offshore-wind lease sales, permitting, or approvals, with a stated duration of >=60 days (or an indefinite pause that explicitly covers at least the next 60 days).
evidence: Regulatory risk for U.S. offshore wind has increased, highlighted by the Revolution Wind halt and legal challenge (CNBC, 2026-01-02).
monitoring_signals: Interior/BOEM press releases and Federal Register notices
Agency guidance to developers (leaked memos reported by Reuters)
White House or Interior public statements on offshore wind policy
predictions.rationale: With active political focus and ongoing litigation, an across-the-board administrative pause is a likely next step, though not certain.

predictions.text: The U.S. Treasury (OFAC) will announce an Iran-related sanctions package designating at least 10 individuals and/or entities in a single action, explicitly tied to protest suppression/human-rights abuses, by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: OFAC press release and SDN updates on the same date show >=10 Iran-related designations and the release explicitly references protest repression, human-rights abuses, or violent suppression of demonstrations as justification.
evidence: U.S. signaled possible intervention if Iran violently suppresses protests, raising escalation risk (CNBC, 2026-01-02).
monitoring_signals: OFAC ‘Recent Actions’ page and SDN change logs
State Department statements on Iran protests
Major media reporting of new U.S. sanctions tied to crackdown
predictions.rationale: Human-rights sanctions are a common, scalable response to escalating protest crackdowns and can be executed quickly without Congress.

predictions.text: The U.S. Department of Justice will publicly announce a civil forfeiture/seizure action involving a named oil tanker (by name/IMO) for sanctions evasion or related violations, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: DOJ press release (or a federal court filing reported by Reuters/Bloomberg/WSJ) confirms a forfeiture complaint, seizure, or restraint of a specific oil tanker (identified by name/IMO) citing sanctions evasion, IEEPA, or related enforcement statutes.
evidence: An oil tanker evading U.S. Coast Guard scrutiny underscores maritime enforcement tensions tied to sanctions and shipping routes (NYT, 2026-01-02).
monitoring_signals: DOJ forfeiture announcements; U.S. Attorney office press releases (SDNY, DDC, etc.)
AIS/shipping analytics reports flagged by Reuters
New court dockets referencing vessel seizures and IEEPA
predictions.rationale: Enforcement intensity is rising, but vessel seizures are operationally and diplomatically complex, lowering probability despite a supportive narrative.

predictions.text: Tesla will announce a company-wide workforce reduction of at least 7% (or at least 10,000 roles) by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Tesla press release, SEC filing, or a Reuters/Bloomberg report citing Tesla confirms a layoff plan meeting >=7% of workforce (or >=10,000 roles).
evidence: Tesla reported Q4 deliveries of 418,227, down 16%, reinforcing demand concerns (CNBC, 2026-01-02).
BYD is set to overtake Tesla as top global EV seller, intensifying competitive pressure (CNBC, 2026-01-02).
monitoring_signals: Tesla internal emails reported by major outlets
WARN notices and LinkedIn layoff tracking
Earnings-call commentary on cost cuts and margin pressure
predictions.rationale: Sustained delivery pressure and intensifying competition often lead to cost actions; however, Tesla may prioritize price/product moves over layoffs.

predictions.text: Tesla will implement MSRP reductions of at least 5% on at least two distinct models in the U.S. in a single coordinated announcement (same day), by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Tesla’s official U.S. website pricing and/or a Tesla press communication, corroborated by Reuters/Bloomberg/major auto press, shows same-day MSRP cuts >=5% for >=2 models (e.g., Model 3, Y, S, X, Cybertruck variants) versus immediately prior listed MSRP.
evidence: Tesla delivery decline and competitive pressure from BYD increase the likelihood of renewed price actions (CNBC, 2026-01-02).
monitoring_signals: Daily MSRP tracking (Tesla configurator archives, auto press)
Inventory/rebate changes and financing promos
Quarter-end delivery push messaging
predictions.rationale: Price is Tesla’s fastest lever to stabilize demand; still, it may rely more on incentives/financing than headline MSRP cuts.

predictions.text: Saks Global (or a primary operating affiliate) will file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the U.S., by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: A Chapter 11 petition is filed (court docket) by Saks Global or a main operating subsidiary, confirmed by company statement or Reuters/Bloomberg/WSJ/FT reporting.
evidence: Saks leadership shake-up and bankruptcy reports signal stress in leveraged retail amid refinancing pressure (CNBC, 2026-01-02).
monitoring_signals: Debt trading levels and covenant amendments
Vendor payment term changes and credit insurance tightening
Store closure announcements and liquidity disclosures
predictions.rationale: High rates and weak discretionary demand raise restructuring odds, but firms often attempt out-of-court exchanges first.

predictions.text: India’s MeitY (or another Indian central authority) will issue a formal written compliance order/notice to xAI referencing Grok and requiring specific safeguards or takedowns related to child sexual content, by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: A publicly reported (Reuters/Bloomberg/major Indian outlets) written government notice/order to xAI is confirmed or reproduced, explicitly referencing Grok and specifying required safeguards/takedown actions regarding child sexual content (or sexualized child images).
evidence: Grok faced regulatory backlash over sexualized child images; India ordered fixes, highlighting rising compliance costs (CNBC, 2026-01-02).
monitoring_signals: Indian ministry statements and notices
xAI policy updates or feature restrictions in India
App store content advisories and platform enforcement notes
predictions.rationale: Given the existing public controversy and India’s history of issuing formal IT Act notices, a documented compliance action is likely.

predictions.text: A bipartisan bill will be introduced in the U.S. Senate to reform the National Emergencies Act by requiring congressional approval to extend a declared national emergency beyond 60 days, by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Congress.gov shows introduction of a Senate bill with at least one sponsor from each party, and bill text includes a requirement for affirmative congressional approval to continue a national emergency beyond 60 days (or a shorter window).
evidence: Reporting highlights erosion of post-Watergate constraints and rising congressional concern about expanding executive tools under Trump’s second term (NYT, 2026-01-02).
monitoring_signals: Congress.gov new bill introductions and press releases from key senators
Hearings or statements from Senate Homeland Security / Judiciary
Advocacy by civil-liberties and business groups about emergency powers
predictions.rationale: Institutional pushback often manifests first as reform bills; passage is uncertain, but introduction with bipartisan sponsorship is plausible.
